awd_titl_txt: Controlling the Dynamics of a Model Filamentous Biopolymer
awd_abstract_narration:
This award by the Biomaterials program in the Division of Materials Research is cofunded by the Cellular Processes program (BIO/MCB). The goal of this research project is to understand how stabilizing and destabilizing factors can tune the dynamics of a model biopolymer. Regulation of the microtubule network is essential to the process of intracellular organization. Microtubule-associated proteins and enzymes control the length and dynamics of single microtubule activity, and thus the network. This project will examine destabilizing enzymes from the microtubule severing enzyme family that is an important group of regulators that can cut microtubules anywhere along the length and cause depolymerization. Additionally, the ability of microtubule stabilizers, such as MAP4 and tau, and their ability to stabilize microtubules alone and to antagonize the activity of severing enzymes also will be studied. Using multi-color total internal reflection fluorescence imaging system, microtubules performing dynamic instability in the presence of fluorescently-labeled accessory proteins will be studied. With this project, both graduate and undergraduate students will be trained at the interface of life sciences and physical sciences. This interdisciplinary training would be very important to prepare them for future industrial and academic careers. The PI has established a strong track record in successfully recruiting and educating students from diverse backgrounds. Recruiting and training of under-represented minority students will be the focus of the planned outreach activities.

The goal of these fundamental scientific studies is to understand how the cell controls the length, growth, and shrinkage of microtubules. Microtubules are filaments found in almost all cells. They support the structure of the cell, and their arrangement into a cell-wide network that is important to organize the inside of cells. In order to understand how microtubules organize the inside of the cell, one must understand how the length, growth, and shrinkage of microtubules themselves are controlled. Experiments will be performed where individual microtubules one-at-a-time will be observed in the presence of other proteins using a specialized microscope. These other proteins could either cut microtubules or protect them. This project is to understand the exact mechanism of tuning on the destructive and constructive proteins that regulate the length, growth, and shrinkage of microtubule. This research will use multi-color single-microtubule imaging by fluorescence microscopy to examine the dynamics of microtubule activity. As part of teaching and training, graduate and undergraduates students will be trained in biological physics at the interface between the physical sciences and life sciences. Biological physics is an important interdisciplinary field that is needed in many industrial and academic careers. As part of this project, underrepresented students will be recruited and trained in the research activities of the investigator.

por.por_cntn:
The scientific goal of this grant was to understand how to control the growth and shrinkage of biologically important filaments in your cells. These filaments are called microtubules and they are made out of protein. They are especially important to cell organization and development from stem cells to specialized cell types, such as nerve cells. They are also essential for the process of cell division, which is also used in development to increase the number of cells in a tissue. In all of these biological processes, microtubules are the structural component – acting like the bones or a tent-pole supporting the cell, but unlike the bones of your body, these cellular bones can grow and shrink over time. This growing and shrinking helps the cell to reorganize during development, create and destroy the cell division machinery to divide the DNA, or just to point the way for cells to move and migrate like white blood cells need to in order to find and destroy pathogens. Yet, we do not understand how these filaments can grow or shrink, or how they are regulated.

In this grant, we explored previously unstudied enzymes that control filament length. We discovered that one important class of filament enzymes, which are known to sever the filaments, are surprisingly turned off by the presence of the protein that makes the filament. When the proteins are in filament form, the filament is a target for destruction. When the protein is free – not in the filament – the protein can bind and stop the enzyme from tearing apart the filament. This important negative feedback loop is essential for ensuring that the enzymes cannot destroy all the filaments in the cell, but was previously completely unknown.

In follow-up work, we have shown that the ability to destroy the filaments from their ends, causing shrinkage, does not depend on the same mechanism as the cutting of the filaments. This is also surprising, and shows us that the destructive enzyme can work in a variety of methods to cause the destruction of the filaments. We have also found that the fuel source for the destructive enzyme, ATP, can inhibit the destruction of the filament when there is too much. This is similar to flooding your engine with gas. As with an car engine, the enzyme we study needs just the right about of fuel. Too little or too much will cause the enzyme motor to stall. These new results are in preparation to be submitted for scientific peer review to vet their validity prior to publication. We anticipate that the reviewers may want more proof to support our claims, but that these results will likely be accepted in the next year.

These exciting, fundamental results about the inner workings of cells are essential to help further our knowledge of how cells function. These results are also important to understand how cells dysfunction in development and disease. In particular, microtubules have a fundamental role in all aspects of cell and tissue development because of their essential supportive nature in cell division and organization. Recent genetic studies have shown that inbreeding of first cousins can result in lissencephaly (smooth brain) and microcephaly (small brain) defects caused by mutations in the destructive enzyme we study. Thus, our work can contribute to the molecular understanding of neuronal development and defects. Our hope is that in the future, our work will help researchers understand where to look early for molecular defects in developing brains.

In addition to the scientific discoveries we have made, the grant funding was also used to support educational and public engagement activities for students from kindergarten to postdoctoral work. Specific activities include summer science camps for under-represented minority women in middle and high school, educational classes on optics for undergraduate and graduate students, and dissemination of the good of scientific research via social media (blogs) and radio broadcasts.
